segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Sensor data from the **Accelerometer**, **Gyrometer**, **Compass**, **Inclinometer**, and **OrientationSensor** classes is defined by their reference axes.
segment.target: Sensor data from the **Accelerometer**, **Gyrometer**, **Compass**, **Inclinometer**, and **OrientationSensor** classes is defined by their reference axes.

segment.source: These axes are defined by the device's landscape orientation and rotate with the device as the user turns it.
segment.target: These axes are defined by the device's landscape orientation and rotate with the device as the user turns it.

segment.source: If your app supports automatic rotation and reorients itself to accommodate the device as the user rotates it, you must adjust your sensor data for the rotation before using it.
segment.target: If your app supports automatic rotation and reorients itself to accommodate the device as the user rotates it, you must adjust your sensor data for the rotation before using it.

segment.source: In order to understand the reference axes for sensors, you need to distinguish display orientation from device orientation.
segment.target: In order to understand the reference axes for sensors, you need to distinguish display orientation from device orientation.

segment.source: Display orientation is the direction text and images are displayed on the screen whereas device orientation is the physical positioning of the device.
segment.target: Display orientation is the direction text and images are displayed on the screen whereas device orientation is the physical positioning of the device.

segment.source: In the following picture, both the device and display orientation are in Landscape.
segment.target: In the following picture, both the device and display orientation are in Landscape.

source.pc: Display and device orientation in Landscape

target.pc: Display and device orientation in Landscape

segment.source: The following picture shows both the display and device orientation in LandscapeFlipped.
segment.target: The following picture shows both the display and device orientation in LandscapeFlipped.

source.pc: Display and device orientation in LandscapeFlipped

target.pc: Display and device orientation in LandscapeFlipped

segment.source: The next picture shows the display orientation in Landscape while the device orientation is LandscapeFlipped.
segment.target: The next picture shows the display orientation in Landscape while the device orientation is LandscapeFlipped.

source.pc: Display orientation in Landscape while the device orientation is LandscapeFlipped

target.pc: Display orientation in Landscape while the device orientation is LandscapeFlipped

segment.source: You can query the orientation values through the **DisplayInformation** class by using the **GetForCurrentView** method with the **CurrentOrientation** property.
segment.target: You can query the orientation values through the **DisplayInformation** class by using the **GetForCurrentView** method with the **CurrentOrientation** property.

segment.source: Then you can create logic by comparing against the **DisplayOrientations** enumeration.
segment.target: Then you can create logic by comparing against the **DisplayOrientations** enumeration.

segment.source: Remember that for every orientation you support, you have to support a conversion of the reference axes to that orientation.
segment.target: Remember that for every orientation you support, you have to support a conversion of the reference axes to that orientation.

segment.source: Manufacturers produce both landscape-first and portrait-first devices.
segment.target: Manufacturers produce both landscape-first and portrait-first devices.

segment.source: When manufacturers integrate components into devices, they do so in a unified and consistent way so that all devices operate within the same reference frame.
segment.target: When manufacturers integrate components into devices, they do so in a unified and consistent way so that all devices operate within the same reference frame.

segment.source: The following table shows the sensor axes for both landscape-first and portrait first devices.
segment.target: The following table shows the sensor axes for both landscape-first and portrait first devices.

segment.source: Devices broadcasting display and headless devices
segment.target: Devices broadcasting display and headless devices

segment.source: Some devices have the ability to broadcast the display to another device.
segment.target: Some devices have the ability to broadcast the display to another device.

segment.source: For example, you could take a tablet and broadcast the display to a projector that will be in landscape orientation.
segment.target: For example, you could take a tablet and broadcast the display to a projector that will be in landscape orientation.

segment.source: In this scenario, it is important to keep in mind that the device orientation is based on the original device, not the one presenting the display.
segment.target: In this scenario, it is important to keep in mind that the device orientation is based on the original device, not the one presenting the display.

segment.source: So an accelerometer would report data for the tablet.
segment.target: So an accelerometer would report data for the tablet.

segment.source: Furthermore, some devices do not have a display.
segment.target: Furthermore, some devices do not have a display.

segment.source: With these devices, the default orientation for these devices is portrait.
segment.target: With these devices, the default orientation for these devices is portrait.

segment.source: Compass heading depends upon the reference axes and so it changes with the device orientation.
segment.target: Compass heading depends upon the reference axes and so it changes with the device orientation.

segment.source: You compensate based on the this table (assume the user is facing north).
segment.target: You compensate based on the this table (assume the user is facing north).

segment.source: API compass heading when facing north
segment.target: API compass heading when facing north

segment.source: Modify the compass heading as shown in the table in order to correctly display the heading.
segment.target: Modify the compass heading as shown in the table in order to correctly display the heading.

segment.source: The following code snippet demonstrates how to do this.
segment.target: The following code snippet demonstrates how to do this.

segment.source: Display orientation with the accelerometer and gyrometer
segment.target: Display orientation with the accelerometer and gyrometer

segment.source: This table converts accelerometer and gyrometer data for display orientation.
segment.target: This table converts accelerometer and gyrometer data for display orientation.

segment.source: The following code example applies these conversions to the gyrometer.
segment.target: The following code example applies these conversions to the gyrometer.

segment.source: The **OrientationSensor** data must be changed in a different way.
segment.target: The **OrientationSensor** data must be changed in a different way.

segment.source: Think of these different orientations as rotations counterclockwise to the Z axis, so we need to reverse the rotation to get back the user’s orientation.
segment.target: Think of these different orientations as rotations counterclockwise to the Z axis, so we need to reverse the rotation to get back the user’s orientation.

segment.source: For quaternion data, we can use Euler’s formula to define a rotation with a reference quaternion, and we can also use a reference rotation matrix.
segment.target: For quaternion data, we can use Euler’s formula to define a rotation with a reference quaternion, and we can also use a reference rotation matrix.

segment.source: To get the relative orientation you want, multiply the reference object against the absolute object.
segment.target: To get the relative orientation you want, multiply the reference object against the absolute object.

segment.source: Note that this math is not commutative.
segment.target: Note that this math is not commutative.

source.pc: Multiply the reference object against the absolute object

target.pc: Multiply the reference object against the absolute object

segment.source: In the preceding expression, the absolute object is returned by the sensor data.
segment.target: In the preceding expression, the absolute object is returned by the sensor data.
